author: sfgate.com
title: Daily Briefing, Oct. 17
text:
Getting it together 
The final US Airways flight took off on an intentionally circuitous round trip Friday between Philadelphia and San Francisco. Flight 1939, named for the airline’s founding year, left Philadelphia International Airport on Friday morning — 31 minutes late (insert your own joke here), headed for scheduled stops in Charlotte, N.C., Phoenix and San Francisco before returning to Philadelphia as a red-eye early Saturday. US Airways was formed in Pittsburgh as All American Aviation, but now its flights will fly under American Airlines, following a merger announced in 2013.
Rides 2.0 
A study by Certify this week shows that ride-hailing services like Uber and Lyft keep taking away more business from taxis and rental cars. At the end of the first quarter of this year, rental cars accounted for half of overall ground transportation, with taxis and ride services having 25 percent each. By the end of the third quarter, though, the tally was rental cars, 44 percent; ride services, 34 percent; and taxis, 22 percent.
D’oh! 
Goldman Sachs Group is dismissing about 20 analysts globally after discovering they had breached rules on internal training tests, people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News. All of them quickly got hired to install smog equipment for Volkswagen .
The Daily Briefing is compiled from San Francisco Chronicle staff and news services. See more items and links at www.sfgate.com . Twitter: @techchronicle
